questions.text: Which of the following statements about the embryonic development of the heart is incorrect?

choices.text: Heart tube is derived from the splanchnopleuric mesoderm.
Truncus arteriosus forms the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.
Bulbus cordis is located at the caudal end of the developing heart tube.
Disappearance of the dorsal mesocardium creates the transverse sinus.

questions.solution:
Bulbus cordis is located at the cranial end of the developing heart tube, not the caudal end.

Formation of Heart Tubes:

  • The endothelial heart tube is derived from the splanchnopleuric mesoderm, located near the pericardial cavity. (Option A)
  • Initially, the heart appears as right and left endothelial heart tubes.
  • These tubes fuse to form a single heart tube.
  • The heart tube has 5 dilatations, which are:
    • Truncus arteriosus
    • Bulbus cordis
    • Primitive ventricle
    • Primitive atrium
    • Sinus venosus
  • Sinus venosus is located at the caudal (venous) end of the primitive heart tube.
    • It consists of a body with two prolongations known as the right and left horns.
    • Right horn: Forms smooth part of the right atrium (sinus venarum).
    • Left horn: Forms coronary sinus.
    • Each horn receives blood from three veins:
      • Vitelline vein
      • Umbilical vein
      • Common cardinal vein
  • Bulbus cordis is the cranial most part of the developing heart tube. (Option C)
    • Forms outflow (smooth) parts of the right ventricle (conus arteriosus) and left ventricle (aortic vestibule).
  • Primitive ventricle: Forms inflow (rough) parts of both ventricles.
  • Primitive atrium: Forms trabeculated part of the right and left atrium.
  • Truncus arteriosus: Forms ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. (Option B)

Formation of Transverse Pericardial Sinus:

  • Heart Tube Folding: Brings the arterial and venous ends closer together.
  • Disappearance of the dorsal mesocardium creates the transverse sinus of the pericardium. (Option D)
  • Parietal and visceral layers of the serous pericardium become continuous at the arterial and venous ends of the heart.
  • Pericardium forms two tubes:
    • One enclosing the aorta and pulmonary trunk.
    • Other enclosing the SVC, IVC, and four pulmonary veins.
  • Two tubes are separated by the transverse sinus of the pericardium.

questions.text: A newborn baby is found to have bluish discoloration of lips, tongue, and nails with poor feeding and signs of congestive heart failure. She is diagnosed with patent truncus arteriosus. What developmental error leads to this condition?

choices.text: Overriding aorta and pulmonary stenosis
Switching of the aorta and pulmonary artery position.
Incomplete closure of interventricular septum
Complete absence of the spiral septum

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Complete absence of the spiral septum

 

Explanation:

The absence of spiral aorticopulmonary septum (AP septum) is a pathologic finding in truncus arteriosus (TA).

Formation of the Bulbus Cordis:

  • The bulbus cordis is the cranial-most region of the primitive heart tube,
  • Originates from the cardiogenic area, a specialized mesoderm region cranial to the prochordal plate.
  • Divides into 3 parts:

Proximal one-third:

  • Merges with the primitive ventricle to form the bulboventricular chamber.
  • Contributes to the trabeculated part of the right ventricle.

Middle part (Conus Cordis):

  • Forms outflow tracts of both ventricles.
  • Two septae are formed in this: proximal and distal bulbar septa.
  • The proximal septum contributes to the interventricular septum.
  • The distal septum divides the conus into the aortic vestibule and conus arteriosus.

Distal part (Truncus Arteriosus):

  • Divides into ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk via the spiral aortopulmonary septum
  • Spiral septum is formed by the fusion of the right superior and left inferior truncus swellings or cushions.
  • Responsible for distributing blood to the body and lungs.

Clinical Significance:

  • Persistent truncus arteriosus: Complete absence of spiral septum. (Option D)

 

  • Ventricular Septal Defects (VSDs):
    • Result from incomplete closure of the interventricular septum, leading to holes in the ventricular wall. (Option C)
    • Symptoms may include shortness of breath and an increased risk of infections.

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot:
    • Comprises four defects linked to abnormalities in the conus and truncus arteriosus:
      • VSD
      • Overriding aorta
      • Pulmonary stenosis (Option A)
      • Right ventricular hypertrophy
    • Can cause cyanosis and impede blood flow to the lungs.
  • Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA):
    • Occurs when the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched due to errors in truncus arteriosus division. (Option B)
    • Requires surgical intervention to correct blood flow issues.

questions.text: An infant's echocardiogram reveals an enlarged coronary sinus. This finding most likely results from an abnormality in which embryological structure?

choices.text: Right horn of the sinus venosus
Left horn of the sinus venosus
Right common cardinal vein
Right vitelline vein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left horn of the sinus venosus

 

Explanation:

Left horn of the sinus venosus regresses during development to form the coronary sinus, so a defect in this structure can result in an abnormal coronary sinus.

Sinus Venosus:

Structure of Sinus Venosus
  • Sinus venosus is the caudal (venous) end of the primitive heart tube, consisting of a body with right and left horns.
  • Each horn is connected to three major veins:
    • Vitelline vein (from the yolk sac)
    • Umbilical vein (from the placenta)
    • Common cardinal vein (from the body wall)

Communication with Atrial Chamber
  • Sinus venosus initially communicates with the primitive atrium through a wide sinoatrial orifice.
  • Grooves appear on the lateral walls of the heart, partially separating the sinus venosus from the atrium.

Regression of the Left Horn

Left horn and its tributaries become reduced in size and become part of the coronary sinus.

Fate of Right Horn (Option A)

Incorporated into the right atrium, forming the smooth-walled part of the right atrium (sinus venarum).

Fate of Sinus Venosus Tributaries
  • Right common cardinal vein becomes part of the superior vena cava. (Option C)
  • Right vitelline vein forms the terminal part of the inferior vena cava. (Option D)
  • Left horn regresses and becomes part of the coronary sinus. (Option B)
  • Left common cardinal vein forms the oblique vein of the left atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cardiac jelly is incorrect?

choices.text: Provide structural support during early heart development
Facilitates end-systolic occlusion, improving pumping efficiency
Store elastic energy during systole for the refilling phase of the heart.
Cellular matrix secreted by the endocardium in the developing heart.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cellular matrix secreted by the endocardium in the developing heart.

 

Explanation:

The cardiac jelly is an acellular matrix that is secreted by the myocardium in the developing heart.

Cardiac Jelly (CJ):

  • A gelatinous, cell-free extracellular matrix filling the myoendocardial space of the embryonic heart tube.
  • Function:
    • Acts as a hydraulic skeleton, providing structural support during early heart development. (Option A)
    • Facilitates end-systolic occlusion of the embryonic heart lumen, improving pumping efficiency. (Option B)
    • Stores elastic energy during systole, aiding the refilling phase of the heart. (Option C)

questions.text: In the image depicting fetal heart development, which structures are labelled as A and B, respectively?

choices.text: A: Ostium primum, B: Ostium secundum
A: Foramen ovale, B: Ostium primum
A: Septum primum, B: Septum secundum
A: Septum secundum, B: Septum primum

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A: Septum primum, B: Septum secundum

 

Explanation:

  • Septum primum (Label A) grows first and contributes to the division of the atria.
  • The septum secundum (Label B) grows later and overlaps the septum primum, forming the foramen ovale, which allows right-to-left blood flow in fetal life.

Septum Primum

 
  • Formed as a sickle-shaped fold from the roof and dorsal wall of the primitive atrium due to pressure from the bulbus cordis.
  • Grows downward toward the atrioventricular (AV) canal and septum intermedium, fusing with the latter.

Ostium Primum

 

Before the septum primum reaches and fuses with the septum intermedium, a gap (foramen primum) allows blood flow between the right and left atria.

Ostium Secundum

Upper part of the septum primum breaks down, creating a new gap (foramen secundum) before the foramen primum closes. The septum primum now has a free upper edge.

Septum Secundum

Grows down from the roof of the atrial chamber, to the right of the septum primum, overlapping the free upper edge of the septum primum as it grows.

Foramen Ovale Formation
  • Overlapping septa create the foramen ovale, allowing blood to flow from right to left atrium during fetal life, preventing left-to-right flow.
  • Patent throughout fetal life.

Obliteration of Foramen Ovale
  • Post-birth, the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs, increasing pressure in this chamber greater than the right atrium, causing fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, closing the foramen ovale.
  • Annulus ovalis (adults) corresponds to the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient is diagnosed with an atrial septal defect (ASD) characterized by a large opening between the left and right atria. Which embryological defect is most commonly associated with this significant type of ASD?

choices.text: Ostium primum defect
Ostium secundum defect
Sinus venosus defect
Coronary Sinus Defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ostium secundum defect

 

Explanation:

Ostium secundum defect is the most common significant ASD characterized by a large atrial opening.

 

Defects in Interatrial Septal Development

  • Atrial Septal Defect (ASD):
    • Varies from total absence of the atrial septum to small openings, such as probe patency of the oval foramen.
    • Most significant defect: Ostium secundum defect, characterized by a large opening between the left and right atria.
    • Causes:
      • Excessive cell death and resorption of the septum primum.

 

      • Inadequate development of the septum secundum.

    • Complete Absence of Atrial Septum:
      • Known as common atrium or cor triloculare biventriculare.
      • Result from complete failure of the septum primum and septum secundum to form.

  • Premature Closure of Foramen Ovale:
    • It can occur during prenatal life.
    • Results in:
      • Massive hypertrophy of the right atrium and ventricle.
      • Underdevelopment of the left side of the heart.
    • Often leads to death shortly after birth.

Ostium primum defect (Option A): Accounts for about 10% of septal defects and develops due to a deficiency in tissue near the atrioventricular valves, making it less common than ostium secundum.

 

Sinus venosus defect (Option B) is located outside the fossa ovalis on the right septal surface. It is associated with anomalous right upper pulmonary venous return rather than a large atrial opening between the atria.

 

Coronary Sinus Defect (Option C) is located in the wall separating the coronary sinus from the left atrium; it may be fenestrated or absent and does not create a significant opening between the left and right atria.

questions.text: During an echocardiogram, a raised ridge is observed around a depression on the interatrial septum. Which structure is most likely involved?

choices.text: Septum primum
Septum secundum
Fossa ovalis
Limbus fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Limbus fossa ovalis

 

Explanation:

Limbus fossa ovalis is the raised ridge surrounding the fossa ovalis.

 

Fossa Ovalis: (Option C)

  • Depressed area located in the lower portion of the right atrial side of the interatrial septum.
  • Remnant of the foramen ovale.

 

  • Septum primum which is on the left atrial side, forms the floor of the fossa ovalis.

 

Limbus Fossa Ovalis: (Option D)

  • A raised ridge (annulus) that surrounds the perimeter of the fossa ovalis.
  • It is formed from the septum secundum, an infolding of the atrial roof.

 

Septum primum (Option A) forms the floor of the fossa ovalis, not the raised ridge surrounding it.

 

Septum secundum (Option B) contributes to the formation of the limbus fossa ovalis but does not directly appear as a raised ridge itself.

questions.text: During the spiraling process of the septum, what anatomical change occurs in relation to the pulmonary trunk and aorta?

choices.text: The pulmonary trunk moves posteriorly.
The aorta moves to the right side of the body.
The pulmonary trunk crosses anteriorly and to the left of the aorta.
There is no change in the position of either vessel.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)The pulmonary trunk crosses anteriorly and to the left of the aorta.

 

Explanation:

  • The spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum positions the pulmonary trunk anteriorly and to the left of the aorta.
  • This arrangement is crucial for separating the pulmonary and systemic circulations.

  • The bulbus cordis elongates into three segments:
    • Proximal part forms bulboventricular chamber
    • Middle part: Conus cordis (outflow tract)
    • Distal part (Truncus arteriosus) develops into the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

 

  • Truncus arteriosus undergoes septation and spiraling.
  • There are two swellings along the truncus arteriosus- truncal swellings distally and conal swellings proximally.
  • The truncal swellings, resembling endocardial cushions, divide the lumen into the proximal ascending aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  • The fusion of truncal and conal swellings establishes the pulmonary trunk’s origin from the right ventricle and the aorta’s origin from the left ventricle, with aortopulmonary valves forming at these fusion lines.
  • Spiraling of the septum allows the pulmonary trunk to cross anterior and to the left of the aorta. (Option C)
  • Failure of neural crest cells to migrate or disruptions to the aorticopulmonary septum leads to congenital heart disease
    • Septation defects:
      • Persistent truncus arteriosus: Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form
      • Tetralogy of Fallot:
        • Anterior and cephalad deviation of the aorticopulmonary septum
        • Comprises four defects linked to abnormalities:
  1. VSD
  2. Overriding aorta
  3. Pulmonary stenosis
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Double outlet right ventricle
  • Spiraling defects:
    • Transposition of the great vessels: Positions of the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched due to errors in truncus arteriosus division.

 

The pulmonary trunk moves posteriorly (Option A): The pulmonary trunk moves anteriorly.

 

The aorta moves to the right side of the body (Option B): The aorta does end up in a more rightward position relative to the pulmonary trunk, but it does not specifically move to the right side of the body.

 

There is no change in the position of either vessel (Option D): The spiraling process specifically reorganizes the positions of the pulmonary trunk and aorta.

questions.text: A newborn presents with significant cyanosis and a single large vessel exiting the heart on imaging studies. The echocardiogram shows a defect in the interventricular septum.What embryological failure led to this condition?

choices.text: Failure of the atrioventricular septum to form.
Failure of the conotruncal ridges to form.
Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral.
Anterior displacement of the septum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Failure of the conotruncal ridges to form.

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the newborn exhibits significant cyanosis and a single large vessel which is suggestive of persistent truncus arteriosus.
  • It resulted from the failure of the conotruncal ridges to develop, which prevents the proper division of the outflow tracts into the aorta and pulmonary artery, leading to the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

 

Aorticopulmonary septum anomalies:

 

1) Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Most common conotruncal heart defect.
  • Cause:

Due to unequal division of the conus and anterior displacement of the septum. (Option D)

Features four cardiovascular issues:

  • Pulmonary infundibular stenosis
  • Overriding aorta
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Tetralogy along with ASD is known as pentalogy of fallot.
  • Common in individuals with Alagille syndrome (also features liver abnormalities and distinctive facial traits).
  • Often associated with a JAG1 gene mutation affecting neural crest cells.


 

2) Persistent Truncus Arteriosus:

  • Cause:
    • Failure of conotruncal ridges to form. (Option B)
  • Features:
    • Leads to a single outflow tract and a defective interventricular septum.
    • The truncus overrides both ventricles.
    • Oxygenated and deoxygenated blood combine, with lung-bound blood entering systemic circulation.Results in congenital cyanotic heart disease.

 

3) Transposition of the Great Vessels:

  • Cause:
    • Occurs when the conotruncal septum fails to spiral correctly. (Option C)
  • Features:s
    • Aorta connects to the right ventricle, pulmonary artery connects to the left ventricle.
    • Patients cannot survive because deoxygenated blood from the body enters the right atrium through the superior and inferior vena cavae, then flows to the right ventricle and into the ascending aorta, bypassing the lungs completely.
    • PDA is essential for survival, allowing blood flow to the lungs for oxygenation.

 

Failure of the atrioventricular septum to form (Option A) refers to atrioventricular septal defects, which involve issues in the separation of the atria and ventricles, not the outflow tracts.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the development of the interventricular septum is incorrect?

choices.text: Muscular part grows from the floor of the bulboventricular cavity
Bulbar part forms from the fusion of two bulbar ridges.
Posterior part of the membranous septum separates the right ventricle from the left atrium.
Interventricular foramen forms above the muscular septum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Posterior part of the membranous septum separates the right ventricle from the left atrium.


 

Explanation:

The posterior part of the membranous septum separates the left ventricle from the right atrium, not the right ventricle from the left atrium.

 

Formation of Interventricular Septum:

The interventricular septum consists of three parts:

  • Muscular part
  • Bulbar part
  • Membranous part

1. Muscular Part:

  • Septum grows upward from the floor of the bulboventricular cavity, dividing it into right and left halves. (Option A)
  • This growth is driven by passive dilation and hemodynamic forces.
  • Septum fuses with the atrioventricular (AV) cushions (septum intermedium).
  • Interventricular foramen forms between the two ventricles at the upper margin of the septum and is eventually closed by the septum intermedium and proximal bulbar septum. (Option D)

2. Bulbar Part:

  • Two bulbar ridges (right and left) arise from the wall of the bulboventricular cavity.
  • These ridges fuse to form the proximal bulbar septum, which grows downward toward the muscular septum but leaves a gap. (Option B)

3. Membranous Part:

  • The gap between the muscular septum and the bulbar septum is filled by tissue from the AV cushions and bulbar ridges.
  • Membranous septum consists of:
  • Anterior part: Separates the right and left ventricles.
  • Posterior part: Separates the left ventricle from the right atrium.(Option C)


Mechanism of Septal Formation: Interventricular septum is likely formed by the downward enlargement of the right and left ventricular cavities on either side of the septum, rather than by active septal growth itself.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which structure allows oxygenated blood to bypass the lungs and directly enter the systemic circulation, ensuring oxygen delivery to the fetal brain and upper body?

choices.text: Ductus venosus
Ductus arteriosus
Foramen ovale
Umbilical vein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

Ductus arteriosus allows most blood from the right ventricle to bypass the lungs by shunting it directly into the aorta, ensuring efficient delivery of oxygenated blood to the fetal brain and upper body.

Fetal Circulation:

Oxygenated Blood Flow:

Placenta → Umbilical Vein → Ductus Venosus (bypasses liver) → Inferior Vena Cava → Right Atrium → Foramen Ovale → Left Atrium → Left Ventricle → Ascending Aorta → Oxygen to head, neck, and upper limbs

 

Deoxygenated Blood Flow:

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) → Right Atrium → Right Ventricle → Pulmonary Trunk → Ductus Arteriosus (bypass pulmonary circulation) → Descending Aorta → Lower body → Umbilical Arteries → Placenta (for oxygenation)

Peculiarities of Fetal Circulation:

  • Ductus Venosus: Directs blood to the inferior vena cava, bypassing the liver and preserving oxygen content. (Option A)
  • Foramen Ovale: Allows equal distribution of blood to both sides of the heart, ensuring more oxygenated blood reaches vital organs in the upper body. (Option C)
  • Ductus Arteriosus: Directs blood from the pulmonary trunk to the aorta, bypassing the lungs and allowing blood to flow to the placenta for oxygenation. (Option B)
  • More oxygenated blood flows to the upper limbs, resulting in longer upper limbs compared to lower limbs in the fetus.

Umbilical vein (Option D) carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, but it doesn’t play a role in shunting blood past the lungs.

  • Its function is to deliver oxygenated blood to the fetal circulation through the ductus venosus.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with cyanosis, rapid breathing, and a machinery-like murmur on auscultation. Echocardiography reveals a left-to-right shunt at the level of the great vessels. Which of the following fetal circulatory changes is most likely responsible for this presentation?

choices.text: Persistent foramen ovale
Patent ductus arteriosus
Closure of ductus venosus
Malrotation of the great arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Patent ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

.

  • A machinery-like murmur in a neonate along with cyanosis and rapid breathing suggests patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

  • PDA is a fetal vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta that normally closes soon after birth.

  • If it remains open (patent), it causes a left-to-right shunt (oxygenated blood from the aorta flows back into the pulmonary artery), leading to volume overload in the lungs, causing cyanosis and respiratory distress.

  • Persistent foramen ovale typically causes a different murmur and shunting pattern; closure of ductus venosus affects liver blood flow; malrotation of great arteries affects vessel positioning, not shunting or murmur.

Changes in the Circulation at Birth:

Umbilical Arteries

Thick muscle walls of the umbilical arteries contract immediately after birth, occluding their lumen. This prevents the loss of fetal blood into the placenta.

Umbilical Vein and Ductus Venosus

Lumen of the umbilical vein and ductus venosus occludes a few minutes after birth, allowing time for fetal blood from the placenta to return to the fetus.

Ductus Arteriosus

Closes initially due to muscle contraction in the vessel wall, and later, intimal proliferation permanently obliterates the lumen, redirecting blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation.

Pulmonary Vessels

Increase in size, allowing more blood to reach the left atrium from the lungs, increasing left atrial pressure.

Foramen Ovale

Increased pressure in the left atrium (due to lung circulation) and reduced pressure in the right atrium (due to cessation of placental blood flow) lead to the closure of the valve of the foramen ovale.

 

Fetal Circulatory Shunts and Their Changes After Birth

 

Fetal Structure

Function During Fetal Life

Remnant

Ductus arteriosus

Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing pulmonary circulation.

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

Shunts blood from the right atrium to the left atrium

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, bypassing the liver

Ligamentum venosum

Umbilical vein

Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus

Ligamentum teres hepatis

Umbilical arteries

Carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery

Distal part: Medial umbilical ligaments

 

Persistent foramen ovale (Option A) allows the shunting of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs.

  • While it can cause cyanosis, the clinical presentation usually doesn't include a machinery murmur, and it is typically asymptomatic or mild compared to PDA.

 

Closure of ductus venosus (Option C) occurs normally after birth and redirects blood flow, but it does not cause shunting or significant symptoms like cyanosis or a murmur.

 

Malrotation of the great arteries (Option D) is a form of congenital heart defect that can cause cyanosis, but it would typically be detected earlier, often with profound cyanosis from birth.

  • Unlike PDA, it does not present with a machinery-like murmur and does not involve a left-to-right shunt.
